reviewText:
Take my starting ship and do battle with the Spanish Galleons. 8 cannons vs 40 cannons.
First 10 minutes of the game and you have one of the biggest ships in the game, dance with the governor's daughter, own your own estate and declare war on the whole Spanish empire.

A full game purely for the 'Pirate' genre. Not some half ♥♥♥♥♥ wannabe.
If you're not happy with any ships, pick a fight with them. Not happy because a port merchant ripped you off during trading goods, bombard the port and take it over. Governor doesn't want to let you see his daughter, control the port and change the governor. Unsatisfied because a country sunk your ship? No problem there, wipe their country off the map by conquering all their ports.

This is a game where skills can beat brute strenght. Wind, ship size, upgrades, tactics and rum is all that matters. Arrrrr!

One of the best, if not THE best pirate games of all time.

reviewText: This is hands down, no lies or embellishments made, the best game I have ever played. Perhaps my experiences are colored by a long lifetime of loving this game, but I have never found something that interests me more, that I can just sit down and play a few hours of and craft a life-story for my character, an entire persona. It's simple really, you are a pirate and the wide open world of the 1600's Carribean is yours for the plucking. The graphics are out of date, the controls are simplistic, and your crew will always get upset no matter how many famous pirates and ships you sink, steal, or scuttle. You can't win, mainly because there is no victory condition. You can save your family, you can get married, you can become the deadliest and most notorious man on the high seas, it's all up to you what you do, who you become, which beach you get marooned on, I love it, I've lived years loving it, I can't recommend this game enough. It isn't for hardcore gamers, don't come in looking to get the highest score, play to relax, it'll work, you'll love it, just, just play the damn game.

reviewText: If you’re an older gamer, then you are more than likely familiar with Sid Meier’s Pirates. It was one of the first games to give you truly open-ended gameplay – you were free to sail under any flag, change allegiances, be a merchant or a pirate … the Caribbean was an open sea for you to explore. The gameplay was pretty straightforward, but it had an engaging quality to it that would cause you to lose yourself in the game for hours on end. Now the game has received a much overdue update and its basic design has withstood the test of time – the game is just as much fun as it ever was, if not more so.The premise of the game is simple: you’re a young buccaneer captain out to make your fortune on the Spanish Main. You’re also out to avenge the capture of you family and rescue them from indentured servitude, but it is really up to you whether or not you want to pursue their rescue. The game will rate your performance more highly if you do, but you can certainly simply concentrate on becoming a feared pirate and leave your family to fend for themselves. The game does not oblige you to do anything.Politics plays a large role in the game as it did in the Caribbean in the 17th Century. The four nations vying for dominance in the region constantly shift allegiances and move in and out of states of war. As an enterprising captain you need to take advantage of this and always be on the look out for new opportunities.The animations are detailed and you’ll see your sails react to the wind as you tack or come about, the wake kicked up by your ship, and even dolphins who come to play in that wake. While sailing the seas you’ll encounter other ships and as you approach you’ll see the flag of their nationality and the ship’s class. Battles on deck are abstracted to a sword dual between you and the enemy captain. You can select a rapier, long sword, or cutlass with which to fight, each of which is a trade off to some degree between speed and defense. You have three attack moves to choose from and a defensive move to counter each.The cities in the game are for far more than sacking. As you sail the Caribbean you’ll see the relative size of each city and be able to tell its relative wealth from the condition of the flag that flies above the town.When in town you have several locations that you can visit. Each town also has a shipwright who can repair your battle damage, buy your captured ships, or in some cases provide upgrades to your hull, sails, or cannons to aid your ship’s performance in battle. Speaking of treasure, it wouldn’t be a pirate game without buried treasure. At the lower difficulty levels maps are always complete and well-marked and it is simply a question of going to the right location and picking up your prize. At higher levels things get a bit trickier as you often have to make do with map fragments and must search for specific landmarks like an arched rock or a clump of dead trees to find the buried booty.Overall Pirates has that hard to pinpoint addictive quality to it that will keep you coming back. Hours will disappear as you strive to complete one more raid or get your next promotion. It’s a magical quality that’s missing in most games, and one that will keep you coming back to Pirates as other games come and go.

reviewText: I guess this game just tickled me right because I loved everything about it. It would be most accurate to describe this game as a collection of mini-games combined into a single experience. There's the land battle mini-game, the ship-combat mini-game, the dancing mini-game, and the fencing mini-game, all connected together by a sailing overworld. I hear a lot of people like the fencing and ship battles but dislike the land-battles and dancing. I liked all of it. And I don't often play musical rhythm games, either.\n\nI'll admit also that playing the whole game has a certain amount of nostalgia appeal for me as well. I played the original in the form of a demo when I was a kid, never got the chance to play the whole thing. Thus closes a previously unfinished chapter of my childhood here.

reviewText: I played the original Sid Meier's Pirates! on Commodore 64 in 1985.  I broke many-a-joystick trying to sail against the wind.  Good times.  This game brought back all of those memories in a massive flood.  I thoroughly enjoyed plundering all sorts of ships, I like the land combat, and the storyline gave the game something to work towards rather than just a blast-and-hack pirate game.  The nostalgia effect was strong, and for die-hard, long-time gamers such as myself, this is a must-have.  Best three bucks I ever spent.

reviewText:
TLDR: I really liked this game, and it really surprised me.

So I bought this game on a whim when it was on sale, a dollar or so. Added it to my steam queue figuring maybe I'd play it when I had nothing better to do. Fast forward a year later and lo and behold, I had nothing better to do, so I booted it up on a whim. I figured it would be a monumental waste of time. This was half right, however not the half I was expecting. This game is somewhat repetitive, sure. But it is deeply satisfying, and it took me a while to figure out why. You can play all kinds of naval war simulators, or sword battle fighting games that are much better than the mechanics of this game. But this had a depth come out of these simple mechanics that made the game a really cool experience. Moreover, this game fairly effectively makes you want to pursue non-combative game play. I'd never given much thought into wanting to dance in a video game before, but it was probably the most fun I'd had in a game, and it wasn't just the novelty. It's easy to make yourself feel like your character has a vested romantic relationship with the woman he is wooing and want to succeed in impressing her with your awesome button pressing skills. It kind of made me want to learn how to dance in real life.

Also, did I mention that you get to be a pirate?

reviewText:
If you ever get the chance to buy this game at a reasonable price, for instance in the recent humble bundle sale or gamefly.co.uk sale, DO IT! This game is my childhood so perhaps I'm biased, but for the 2,50€ I paid for this game it's a steal.

Although relatively short, you'll finish it in around 15 hours if you don't waste too much time, Sid Meier's Pirates! includes a variety of era's to play (1600-20, 20-40, ... , 80-1700) each with a different twist to it.

As you progress your difficulty will be ramped up slightly if you want to, however for people who want a real challenge I dare you to try out swashbuckler without losing a ship.

Good aspects:
-Replayable
-Variety of Ships to take
-Ability to conquer cities and create your own 'world'

Negative aspects:
-Repetitive mechanics (Dancing, Fencing, Naval warfare)
-No 'endless' mode available

reviewText: Beyond the nostalgia I feel for this game, it is genuinely an incredibly well made game for its time. Open world (ocean) exploration, controll over your fleet and what kind of ships are in it, as well as multiple quest lines and missions to do (become the most notorious pirate, get with a governors daughter, save your long lost family etc). The combat is easy to get the hang of (it's basically just timed events, but with combos) but if you pick a more difficult playing mode it legitimately can be excruciatingly dificult, so you can't get bored with it really as long as you keep yourself on a game difficulty that works for you. I deeply recommend this game, especially when it's on sale.

reviewText:
Sid Meier's Pirates! is a pirate adventure game. After a mutiny that put you at the helm of your own ship, you and your pirate crew arrive in the Caribbean to find fortune as you seek to avenge your family from those that did it wrong.

Pros: Every tropes you ever saw about pirates are there: build your reputation and ranking with the four European factions, while also dealing with the clergy, the natives and the pirate community, compete against the most notorious pirates in history while using pieces of maps to find their buried treasure or the lost cities of gold, do ship-to-ship combat against raider, merchant, military or other pirate vessels, flirt with the governor's daughters by impressing her in the ballroom. The game is easy to pick up regardless of difficulty level, navigating, ship-to-ship combat and swordplay are simple. 27 different type of ships sail the sea, any of which can be captured, each with different storage and crew capacity, optimal wind angle, speed and turning speed. Ship-specific upgrades are available at various ports, capturing ships might get get you permanent specialists for your crew, a variety of items can be purchased in taverns. The graphics are bright and colorful and animations are smooth.

Cons: The graphics are showing their age. Sid Meier's Pirates! borders on the casual game, as it's basically a collection of multiple mini-games: fighting, dancing, ship-to-ship combat, swordplay, city sacking, all mini-games with little depth. City conquering strategy is extremely simplified, and the game lacks any realism of the hardships of being at sea. Capturing ships will become repetitive after a few playthrough. The map is always the same, varied only by the chosen timeline or occasional city conquest of a rival European faction.

Verdict: ★★★☆☆ - It's up to you

Overall, this is a fun game, and that's all it aims to be: fun. It isn't a seafaring simulator, it isn't an action sword-fighter, it isn't a trade simulator and definitively isn't a strategy game. If you're looking for a nice, easy and fun game worth its price, then I'll recommend you give Sid Meier's Pirates! a try!

—————————————————————————
This was just my opinion.

If you found this review helpful, please consider giving it a thumbs up, and feel free to check out more of my (purely opinionated) reviews.

reviewText:
It's the best pirate game I've ever played. It's also one of the very few pirate games I've ever played, so I dunno if my review will count for much.

Surprisingly addicting open-world pirate game where you can go out and do random stuff, like rescue your family from this villain, go treasure hunting, attack other ships and/or settlements, acquire goods from one port and selling it at another port (trading), and even wooing (and eventually marrying) a random daughter of a govenor. There's fun mini games (although lots of people hate the dancing one) and you basically play until you grow too old to continue pirating. Keep watch of the morale of your crew at sea or they may end up deserting you!

Only bad thing I found with the game is that the main character whom you play as doesn't look manly enough for my liking, and while I like the dancing mini-games, it tends to go on for too long. If it was a shorter mini-game, it would've been much better.

reviewText:
WOW. Sid Meier's Pirates! A true classic, in almost every way imagineable. I've played a lot more of this way back when.

Gameplay:
+Lovely fun.
+The free choice of the game is awesome. Be a ruthless pirate, a mercenary, a trader, a romantic, a dueller, or all of them.
+Faction system and promotions are very well done.
+There's a ♥♥♥♥♥on to do, and I never feel bored.
+Different ships for different playstyles.
+2nd game has advanced startup.
+Pretty large map.
+The perfect amount of water.
+Get married, own land, dance, essentially Capitalism Simulator 1660. Sort of.
+-The easiest difficulty has wind always facing west.
+-Non-customizable character, besides from items purchased from travellers, and that's barely customization. Mods, though.
+-Sneaking into town is average.
-You can't destroy enemy strongholds by sea by spamming the Spacebar.
9/10

Story:
+It's alright, something out of a 19th century novelist or Hollywood.
+Your family was captured, and, in the course of the game, you must rescue them and  find the man who wronged your family and essentially harm him.
+Lots of side quests.
+-Voice acting is suiting, but doesn't hit the right cords often.
+-The health mechanic is interesting, but ruins a good game when you retire not fufilling a lot.
7/10

Graphics:
+For it's time, great.
+It has surprisingly aged well, for a game made 11 years ago.
+The water looks nice, even on Intel graphics cards.
+Intel Graphic Card friendly.
-Some land spots look a bit... Meh.
8/10

Music/Sound:
+Kickass.
+There's music to dancing, swordfighting, naval combat, trading, the tavern... A whole bunch. And it's well done.
+Sound is alright, too.
+-Hero's voice.
-The govenors sound like they're the High-Class Extrodinare, while true, somewhat annoying.
7/10

Concensus: I give Pirates! an 8.5/10. A gaming classic, that has truly aged well. Pick it up if you havn't.

DayZ Review Gimmick: I was a bad dancer. The govenor's daughter turned me down. She laughed. I laughed when I sacked her town and gave it to the English. 8.5/10

reviewText:
There's so much to like. I've spent hundreds of hours on this game. All the other pirate games fall short; this is the gold standard. It's a must have for any gamer of any level. It's terribly addictive and fun.

Sid, please give us an update to this almost perfect game!

I'd like to see the map expanded a bit to include more opportunities in America, a few more mini-games and side missions, and maybe a game ending mission after you've played a perfect pirate and ready to retire. But don't change much; the gameplay is outstanding, the storyline is great, the attention to detail unmatched.

Sid Meier's Pirates just might be the most entertaining game I've ever played.

reviewText:
I downloaded this game with the Sid Meiers humble bundle. I wasn't originially very excited for it, because I had only bought the bundle for the civ games but after playing this game for a few hours, I'm happy it was included.

The game is a little confusing at first, but after playing for a little it becomes a bit easier to understand. However, I still have no idea what the main objective is besides the fact that you're a pirate looking to save his family (that much is clear from the intro). As far as I know you don't have to follow the main quests or any of that really, you can just plunder riches or charm governors daughter until retirement.

After about 3.5 hours, I'm still not bored with the pirate life. I still haven't fully discovered all of the game, but the parts I have discovered are what makes this game addicting. I fully recommend this to anyone who enjoys strategy or even just pirates.

reviewText:
BEST ABOUT IT:  The open ended nature, sailing around picking on ships that outclass you, and managing your fleet and supplies.

WORST ABOUT IT:  The quicktime event dancing and fencing scenes are downright awful and the mere thought of them is usually enough to prevent me from playing this game.

GAMEPLAY:  You start by choosing a country to side with and a small sloop in that chosen country's port.  You can get some info and supplies from that port and then you're off to sail around the Caribbian.  The ship controls feel fantastic, working with or against the wind, and there is strategy in what type of cannon shot you fire, round to damage a hull, chain to damage the sails, and grape to take out crew.  You also need to buy or raid supplies to keep your crew from a mutiny.

CONTROLS:  Steering your ship and firing the cannons is very satisfying.  However the UI and map screens are clunky and seem like from an age prior to when this game was released.  The QTE cut scenes are obnoxious and repetitive but they can mostly be avoided altogether.

STORY:  You play as a young pirate who is trying to rescue his family and defeat some marquis villain.  This is a sandbox game so you’ll be creating your own story for the most part.  There's no way to customise your character other than your name and some stat bonuses (1 perk at the start and others with items), but you can captain any ship you can get your hands on and deck it out with upgrades.

GRAPHICS:  The main graphics look Caribbean and still mostly hold up today and are certainly functional, but the cut scenes look dated.  You have to use your imagination a bit.  The highest screen resolution is 1152 x 864 and no widescreen.  It looks ok though, and there are ways to force the resolution if you want.

PERFORMANCE:  Ran smoothly for me and I didn't encounter any problems.

SOUND:  Excellent.  The sounds of the waves, creaking of the wooden ships, and shouts of your crew are some of the first things that come to mind thinking of this game.  I’m not a fan of the Simlish spoken dialect though.  The music is fitting and sets the cartoony pirate mood well.

REPLAYABILITY:  Replay doesn’t get any better than this game.  However I haven’t actually finished the story yet, it's just fun to sail around and do your own thing.

SIMILAR TO:  I don’t know, the Sims 2 mixed with Grand Theft Auto 1 and Port Royale?

RECOMMENDED PURCHASE PRICE:  I don't see this on sale often but $10 is reasonable.


Sid Meier’s Pirates
Firaxis Games 2004 (remake of 1987 original)

RATING:  75/100

reviewText:
Full Disclosure: Used to play this game back in its hey-day long before its Steam release. Bought it again during a previous sale just to reminisce, and its just as good as it was back then.

One of the classics of Sid Meier's earlier days, brought forward to 2005, as whimsical and as rewarding as it was back then as it is now, only hampered by lack of more modern-day support features like widescreen, stability on more modern OS's, etc.
+ Colorful, light-hearted portrayal of the Golden Age of Piracy, with art direction that holds up to today, 2005-era warts and all.
+ Still-unique controls (using the numpad keys) make it one of the more unusual yet easiest to approach and play games to date. You can play this entire game one-handed if you wish.
+ A truly open seas adventure, with only the barest of poking about the overarching story involving revenge and skullduggery. Combine this freedom with solid sea battle mechanics, sword combat, and dancing to impress the local governor's daughter and you've got something unique every run.
+ In classic Sid Meier's style, many options to set player difficulty, including the option to ante up" at each "dividing the loot" point after ever expedition with a crew.
+ Yar har fiddle de dee you are a pirate~!

- 2005 warts and all. No widescreen support. Lack of modern OS support (with some display issues on Win7 machines). May want to play this in a window and set your expectations of graphical fidelity properly.
- Bit of a conundrum if you do not own a keyboard with a numpad.
- Some would argue that the seas battle mechanics are a bit shallow
date: the sword combat can be difficult to get into
recommended: and the dancing is nigh impossible.\n- In classic Sid Meier's style
hoursPlayed: game can be haphazard in difficulty gaps between the given difficulties.\n- Not a ninja. Or a wizard. In space."

reviewText:
This is a fun, casual game.  It is not, by any means, deep, but it's still enjoyable to mess around with.  You play the game as a pirate in the Caribbean pre-Johnny Depp.  You can play the game during various historical settings which basically have the effect of changing how much variety there is in terms of the different national factions.  The later you set the game, the more likely you'll see major French, Dutch, and English ports.  By contrast, in the earlier settings, it's far more Spanish-dominated.

This can have an effect on how you play the game.  With more factions, you have more ability to behave like a true pirate, sinking or taking vessels of various factions, and then doing the same to whomever they're at war with (and they're always at war with someone...).  When it's just the Spanish, you have to try playing a minigame where you sneak into the Spanish port, risking imprisonment.  Speaking of the minigames, they're generally good fun, if occasionally repetitive and annoying.  The dancing in particular can get tedious, but at least you're usually well rewarded.

As I mentioned, the game isn't particularly deep.  It's not as if you're running a wooden ship simulator.  The game's graphics are dated, but acceptable.  They were fortunately done in a cartoony" style
date: so they age a bit better than supposedly cutting-edge visuals from the same era (2004)
recommended: which now fall squarely into "uncanny valley" territory.\n\nAnyway
hoursPlayed: it's a good game
voteText: and usually available on Steam for dirt cheap.  You'll definitely get your $2-5 worth out of this title."

reviewText:
An entertaining and highly addictive pirate simulator. You won't believe how much fun it is.

Most of the game is played in a top-down mode where you control a ship that can travel between ports buying and selling goods and engage in naval combat with other ships. Wind speed and direction play a role, but you can generally travel into the wind without the need for tacking. Your ship has up to three weapons which target the enemy ship's hull, crew, and sails. There are about 10ish ship upgrades, which you can buy at specific ports. You can capture extra ships and build a fleet, but you only ever control the flagship and the remaining ships just add extra crew and cargo.

The rest of the game consists of a number of minigames and dialog trees.

- There is a sword fighting minigame that plays like a very basic fighting game. You mainly play this against enemy captains to capture their ships.

- There is a dancing minigame where you must react to a sequence of quicktime events in order to win the hearts of maidens. This is not much fun and is the worst part of this otherwise excellent game.

- There is a buried treasure minigame where you walk about on land looking for buried treasure.

You need to divvy up your loot with your crew periodically, at which point you lose your fleet and most of your gold and crew. You'll advance via the items you acquire and your quest progression, but much of the rest of your possessions will come and go over the course of the game.

There is a plot about rescuing your kidnapped family, but this isn't really a story-driven game. Most of the actual gameplay is about capturing ships and searching for treasure.

Yaar!

reviewText:
This game is great if you've ever wanted to sail around capturing ships, being promoted, and beating other famous pirates. The different ships are quite interesting, though I haven't yet found a giant grand frigate or anything yet, it is still quite captivating. The various quests add depth into the game, and you will find yourself dueling for the win, litterally!

The only drawback to all of this that I have found is the wind. You may find yourself going quickly in one direction, and slowly in another, while your crew may be near starving, or you are badly in need of repairs, or you're out of crew members. Also, some of the fights that i've done are quite annoying, as the computer will block your strike, and counter several times in a row, effectively leading to a loss.

Aside from that, this game is great, and captivating for anyone who enjoys the era of being able to plunder the royal navies, or capture ports for another country. Nice job devs!

reviewText:
Sid's Meier's Pirates! Has a place in my heart as being one of the first few games I have ever played on my old college laptop, I remember playing this game and having so much trouble getting it to run on a laptop (which doesn't have a keypad, everything was done with a mouse or scroller pad)

Anyway about the game, what can I say, it's a simple and linear game, but that's what makes it so likable I suppose, it's a game where your quest is set out for you early on, and you decide how long you want to take to pursue those quests. However there is a time limit as you age in this game (yes you age)

I have to say by today's standards, it's quite linear but for a game of it's age, I must say it certainly stood the test of time, and if you have some extra cash leftover, pick it up, simple clean fun that's just good for a casual gaming experience.

I'd recommend it for sure, but only if you'd like to try something casual for a change. 6/10

reviewText:
Might be one of the greatest games ever made.

I enjoyed it immensely as a child and I enjoy still as an adult. The game play is simple and fun. You are a pirate sailing the Caribbean. You sail, sword fight, capture ships, woo maidens, and dig up buried treasure; all while trying to locate and save your long lost family. No two game plays are alike, and I've never encountered another pirate game quite like this one... Lord knows I tried.

Because I am 6, my Pirate is the notorious captain Tite Hassole. Captain Hassole is a proud duke in the Spanish armada, until it suits him. He then raided the city Margarita about 3 times and turned it into the Dutch Port of Margarita, because reasons. Tite was also a bit of a player and while he would beat a hasty retreat from any plain governor’s daughter, at least 6 times, Tite Hassole gave all the crew's money away to get a ring for a lovely lady or two.

A constant issue for me is the repetitiveness of the sword fighting, and to top it off I'm not that great at it. It becomes essential to know how to sword fight well, especially in the late game, but I never got over my smash slash really quick" routine.

All in all a solid game
date: well worth the money and real nostalgia trip for me."

reviewText:
While I don't have many hours clocked on steam for this game, I played hundreds of hours of it a decade ago. I basically bought it in case I ever have kids, or run into people who for some friggin reason haven't played this jewel. Aspects of it haven't exactly aged well. It's incredibly male-centric, you can't play some rockin pirate queen and romance the mayors of towns or their sons - and that's a shame.

The game could use some basic mod tools to open it up for a new generation - especially since a ground-up remake is unlikely.

STILL - the gameplay itself is perfect. Each aspect of the game is deep enough to mesh with the other elements, and it gets surprisingly complex at the meta level. Watch a gameplay video on youtube, if it looks delightful to you - buy it - at any price. If it looks like something you wouldn't enjoy playing, give it a pass.

Regardless I consider this to be THE definitive pirate game. (as of 2015)

reviewText: Even over a decade later, the remake of Sid Meier's Pirates! is still arguably the best pirate game around. Most of the main mechanics of the game have been copied over the years as flash games and freemium mobile games, but the 3D graphics and minigames in this version make it worth a few bucks if you like that sort of game. I wouldn't pay full price for it, but at $2.50 it's a good pickup and you're sure to get a couple of hours of fun out of it.\n\nJust as a side note, this game really wants you to use a numpad. It literally BEGS you to do so. I have been playing without, and while a little clunkier it isn't awful. The game has an onscreen numpad that you can click on to achieve the same effect. However, the game does turn on NumLock without telling you, and since my laptop keyboard doesn't have a NumLock button, I was very confused when my p" key started typing "*". I had to pull up the onscreen keyboard to turn it off. Again
recommended: just be aware that this happens."

reviewText:
This game has a very special place in my heart. I grew up playing the NES version for hours and hours, and I imagine I'll be playing this version in much the same way. While this 'new' version is well over ten years old it's still such a wonderful and exciting game that only a pirate game of the highest caliber would be able to take it's position as Admiral of the fleet.

What makes this such an incredible game is the sandbox aspect of it. The player can really pursue just about any path that pleases them. Would you like to honor your selected nation by protecting its cities from invasion, boosting its economy by plundering other nations trade goods, and making the seas a place feared for anyone that doesn't fly your flag? You can. Would you like to cast all allegiance aside and plunder the nations of their gold and goods? Go to it. Want to become a master dancer, have a wife in each corner of the map, and become the Romeo of the high seas? Your ship awaits. If you want to create a massive fleet of warships and attack towns you can do that as well. Sid Meier's Pirates is truly one of the most incredible sandbox experiences available, incredibly replayable, fun, fast, engaging, and the best pirate game available.

Highest recommendations for anyone that enjoys this period of history, pirates, nautical adventures, and ballroom dancing.

reviewText:
This game was my childhood. Although I have barely played on steam, I have spent hundreds of hours of my life in this.
the game is easily one of the best pirate games around, except for maybe AC Black Flag. even getting it was a mission because it's not sold in my country. But I found a random dude in another country to buy it on my behalf. Good guy +rep.

You embark on a personal mission to rescue you family from evil villain.
Find the minion, find the map, find family member get more maps.
Eventually you get all the map pieces and rush the fort.

The sea battles are entertaining.
the fencing and swordplay are fun.
But the ballroom dancing, that is intense, especially on harder difficulties.

It's also one of the few games to have aging as a mechanic for you but no-one else.
You have a finite amount of time to win the game.
Start as a teenager and when you are 70 or so, the dude who kidnapped your family, is still the same age and reallly hard to beat.

Sail around, listen to cheerful piraty songs, dig up treasure and defeat famous pirates in laughably easy duels, depending on your difficulty.

There are loads of different ships to capture and add to your fleet.
And stingy methods to avoid paying your crew. (one of my favourite is to get most of them killed so that their share is really high and they don't get upset.)

And when they mutiny agaisnt you, stealing your other ship and heading to port.
There shall be no survivors.

reviewText:
Normally I'm not big on remakes, be it movies, games, or anything else. However this is one remake that comes damn close to living up to the legend of the original. I used to spend hours playing this game on the venerable Commodore 64, then on the Amiga, and again on the old 486..

First up, I will confess that I prefer the original, especially the Amiga and PC versions, but I still enjoy having a lash at this now and then. I actually bought this game when it was released, but the disc has since succumbed to bit rot, so when I saw this on sale the other day I had to buy it.

The addition of extra subgames adds to the fun and there are many other small improvements such as being able to battle multiple ships at a time. The audio and the visuals suit the game well and the addition of cut scenes enhance the games charm.

While it may be nostalgia that draws me to this game, I still heartily recomend it. I also recomend that people try out Pirates! Gold Plus (comes with the original 1987 game and the early 90's remake) so they can get a taste of what made the game such a classic, and why Sid Meier has long been considered a legend.

4/5

reviewText:
Sid Meier's Pirates is not only an interesting exploration into the world of necromancy but also an engaging PSA about recycling.

The game is continuously stuck in some sort of tutorial mode from the first to third difficulty where it punishes you for trying to make the game harder by stealing all of your gold. As soon as you hit Swashbuckler however the game becomes a torment where everything from wind, your crew and even your family hates your guts and wishes to destroy you.

The final difficulty however isn't even mentioned by most players who can give you hundreds of strategies for Swashbuckler but not a single for Rogue. It really is just better to forget that this difficulty even exists. It will test your limits as it rips every shred of humanity from you until you're either begging for mercy or some kind of robotic killing machine of the colonial seas. No matter how good you are on Rogue the swordfight with the final boss in his fortress has been designed as a testing protocol for T-800 units instead of being a game for actual human beings to complete.

Oh and good luck with the dancing minigame.

reviewText:
I saw this game and after a sale I picked it up.  I was a bit hesitant to play it as I had a few recent encounters where I should have left the old games in my memory as they just didn't withstand the test of time.

This one, however, is still just as awesome now as it was when I first played it.

I have played a lot of pirate sim games over the years, and this one, to me, is by far the best.  There is so much to do and so many ways to play - it offers a ton of replayability.  It has all the ship combat, treasure hunting, town raiding, dark alley sneaking, and ugly daughter avoiding thrills I remember and they are just as fun as ever!

A very easy to learn and use interface lets you get right into it and start buckling all the swashes you can handle!  I really can't recommend the game enough, especially if it is on sale (for $2.50 USD at the time of this review).  In terms of a game you can play for a few minutes when you're bored or spend a day with those swashes we just talked about, you can count on Sid Meiers Pirates! being there for you!

reviewText:
Do you like pirates? Yes? Well then we have the game for ye matey!

General: Sid Meier's Pirates!(I will refer to it as SMP! from now on) is a... pirate RPG... I guess? You take command of a young pirate and sail through the Caribbean in a strategy-ish POV. Your goal is to rescue your family from the clutches of gang of evil spanish dudes without dying. Now dear reader you will say well of course you shouldn't die that is quite obvious. Well it is not, in SMP! you only have a limited time to plunder until you are too old for the sea. That means be quick and find as many unique items that will prolong your life as possible.

Visuals: SMP! looks due to it's sunny style and perspective quite good even for todays standarts.

Audio: The sounds are not always synced with what is happening but are not bad enough for you to generally notice.

Open World: The World feels incredibly alive as the differnet nations go to war, cities change their owner and missions are not as static as in other games.

Gameplay: In SMP! you there are 2 kinds of missions, the ones that are directly tied to the story and side missions. Both however sometimes randomly collide as the Baron that kidnapped your family has also kidnapped your fiance.  Long story short: everything that you see in the world is something you can do" and all of those activities are worth it
date: the Seas have tough spots and it all feels very alive. (Almost) Nothing that has to be triggered the old-fashioned way in a wacky sunny-pirate setting that reminds me of movies like "Mutiny on the Bounty".\n\nStory: While in itself the game offers a decent revenge story
recommended:
the way the missions work make the game drag on.Basicly you hunt down those corrupt spanish guys to get information on the location of your family members(that look just like the day you lost them). However you will have to repeat this hunt multiple times to get to one of your family members. This is probably the only major problem the game has and even that is not that bad since there is more to do besides the Story missions.

Final Verdict: Alive happy-go lucky Pirate awesomeness. SMP! is one of my favorite games and I can only recommend buying it especially if you like Pirates.

~Captain AndGeo"
hoursPlayed: August 8, 2014

I honestly didn't think much of it even after seeing gameplay and the trailers and such, but I had like $3 to spare and the sale was on and I was like hey, there are so few pirate games I might as well own this one too.

Man, that was the best decision I made during that sale. This is probably the best pirate game there is right now, and yes I've played ♥♥♥ Creed's Black Flag (And adored it)

reviewText:
Short review: BUY IT! Heaps of fun, and lots of hours of gameplay. (my play time is under-represented as I own the DVD version).

Long review:
Sid Meier's Pirates brings a classic game to a new generation. I remember when the original game came out, and spent many, many hours sailing the high seas - generally ending up not much higher than a pauper in the original score board at the end. Make money pirating, loot towns, rescue your family - all while under commission from the Dutch, English, French or Spanish, becoming a Duke for all 4 nationalities if you pick your targets right.

This remake has a few changes from the original that in my opinion improve the gameplay, though that view is not shared by everyone.

The new dance feature adds challenge to wooing the governers daughters. The previous a simple dialog choice of polite conversation, flirting or marriage offers was replaced with a complex dance scene, which increases in difficulty based on skill level and attractiveness of the woman in question. If you have any musical background, this is not too challenging as all dance moves are 8 bar sequences so you don't need to look for every hand gesture once you learn them. Those who dislike this feature however will find it a huge obstruction to gameplay, as many special items, maps, and information can be obtained this way. While you can get everything elsewhere, it takes much longer.

Open-world nature of the game means endless replayability - side with different nationalities, declare piracy on everyone, play in different eras when towns are hugely fortified or not - each choice effects the overall difficulty and your final wealth and happiness. Very addictive.

Recommended :)
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText:
It's difficult to beat a classic, isn't it?
In Sid Meier's Pirates, you play as an unnamed man who seeks vengence for his wrongfully captured family. In doing so you get the chance to captain a ship in the golden age of piracy and plunder and pillage to your heart's content! That is, if you don't care for every nation sending their best to hunt you down. But let's face it, you only need to worry about that on the higher difficulties.
Most of the game is spent sailing your ship between ports, and doing whatever you feel like doing in the process, whether that be pillaging traders, hunting pirates, obtaining proffesional and eventually noble ranks with one of four nations (or all of them if that's how you swing), trading (stolen) goods, finding treasure or romancing the governor's daughter. It's all there and ready for you to sink your teeth into.
Some of the more exciting features include ship-to-ship combat, swordplay, dancing at the ball, besieging cities and of course spelunking. Although the naval combat is the most prolific of these, you'll likely also find a lot of enjoyment in besting the finest pirates ever to sail in swordplay and then digging up their buried treasures just to spit at their watery graves.
As far as story goes, it's alright. The backstory gives you just enough to set out after the villain (whose name I shan't attempt to spell out for the sake of my sanity) and try to rescue your remaining family. Finding your family is like a treasure hunt in itself, only with a different kind of reward at the end.
All in all, this is probably one of the best games I've ever played, regardless of genre. I might be slightly biased, since I used to own a physical copy of this game before Steam even existed, and played it so much that it eventually was scratched beyond salvation. Still it's a testament to its entertainment value that anyone would play it that much. And now I've got it on my computer once again...
Well, reality is overrated anyway. So long everybody! :D

reviewText:
Ahoy, matey! The objective of this game is to become the most notorious pirate in the Caribbean. Together with your band of pirates you will explore the Carribean, ransacking towns, wooing the mayor's daughters, fighting notorious pirates, and attacking ships for their gold, food, and luxuries as you work your way up the pirate ranks. This game REALLY provides a strong pirate experience.

I didn't enjoy Sid Meier's Civilization games because even though I liked the macro management of the civilization anytime I would order units to perform an action, I wanted to be there in the action and not just watch a sim play out. I really love games that give you a macro management but let's you take part in the lower level actions. Because of this I was skeptical that I would like this game. But I can assure you, this game is NOT like that. This definitely feels more like an adventure game with a sim as a backdrop and several mini-games thrown into the mix. The game is completely nonlinear and really doesn't have an ending as you can keep playing as long as you like. The story is weak so don't expect a strong narrative. One annoyance I had initially with the game was that there are no keybindings setup and you can't set them up in the game, so you have to manually edit the game's configuration file to the keys you want, but once that's done I found combat and dancing much easier. I highly recommend using keys for the sword fighting and dancing.

Pros:
+ Nonlinear gameplay
+ Strong pirate theme
+ Good music

Cons:
- No key bindings settings in-game.

I highly recommend buying this game. It's worth every penny even at regular price.

reviewText:
This is a great game. Take on the evil Spanish, greedy Dutch, slimy French, or perfidious English for fame and fortune. The progression system is truly great. Your life is split up into voyages the dength depending on how fast you can accumulate gold and how much crew you have. After each voyage you split the loot and get to increase or stay at the same difficulty, at higher difficulty you get to keep a larger share. You also get slower as you age which increases difficulty in some aspects of the game.

The attention to detail is also substantial. Every faction has their own feel to them and they send out ships of their own with special missions that affect which nations are at war, the wealth and size of towns, their defence and even their allegiance. You can intercept or guard these ships to affect wether or not their mission will be successful.

It also feels that there is nothing missing, and I was surprised at how many different things you could do. You could just trade, or you could fight a war, and everything in between. Sink ships or capture them, loot towns in land battles and install a governor of your liking, woo ladies in every town and even marry, search for treasure, lost cities, captured family members and love interests. There are lots of different ships with different stats, pick which suits your style best or keep a fleet so you have many options. Upgrade your ships and buy rare items to boost your own stats. Even the sailing is a mini game in itself as you try to make use of storms and wind to get where you want faster. As I said there's so much to do but nothing is hidden in some obscure corner that requires reading a manual to experience.

My personal best thing with this game is that there are never any fetch quests" so common in other rpg's
date: instead you are totally free to do whatever you like. Once you have captured a criminal there's never that annoying unnessecary return trip to turn him in. Raising your military rank is done by simply helping your nation in any way you want. You don't need to talk to someone first
recommended: just declare what you have done to any governor and he'll promote you accordingly.\n\nThere are a couple negatives though. No ship can sail very well against the wind this means the game can slow down from its otherwise fast paced tempo. This is also not very realistic as some of the ships in the game sailed better than this. The tretirement occupation you get is also kind of breaking the immersion as even though you are a duke with thousands of acres of land and plenty of money you may get something like farmer or innkeeper just because you didn't get revenge
hoursPlayed: found all family members or got married. Otherwise a flawless game.\n\nIRemember how civilization has the mantra "just one more turn" this game although not turn based gives you the same feeling: There's always just one more thing you need to do before you can save and continue later."

Sid Meier's Pirates brings a classic game to a new generation. I remember when the original game came out, and spent many, many hours sailing the high seas - generally ending up not much higher than a pauper in the original score board at the end. Make money pirating, loot towns, rescue your family - all while under commission from the Dutch, English, French or Spanish, becoming a Duke for all 4 nationalities if you pick your targets right.

This remake has a few changes from the original that in my opinion improve the gameplay, though that view is not shared by everyone.

The new dance feature adds challenge to wooing the governers daughters. The previous a simple dialog choice of polite conversation, flirting or marriage offers was replaced with a complex dance scene, which increases in difficulty based on skill level and attractiveness of the woman in question. If you have any musical background, this is not too challenging as all dance moves are 8 bar sequences so you don't need to look for every hand gesture once you learn them. Those who dislike this feature however will find it a huge obstruction to gameplay, as many special items, maps, and information can be obtained this way. While you can get everything elsewhere, it takes much longer.

Open-world nature of the game means endless replayability - side with different nationalities, declare piracy on everyone, play in different eras when towns are hugely fortified or not - each choice effects the overall difficulty and your final wealth and happiness. Very addictive.

Recommended :)

reviewText: It's a pretty good game for being so cheap and old but far too outdated. Not by graphics or gameplay mind you (though land battle is a **JOKE**), but because control configuration is a total pain in the ♥♥♥. Numpad keys just do not work at all for me in the game (yes I tried numlock). There seems to be a 2 second delay or so where I have to hold the key down. Tried modifying the INI file setting numpad to QWEASDZXC, but apparently the A and D keys are hard-coded for zoom or something so my ship zooms in and out constantly. They're not in the INI file. Tried use auto hotkeys or whatever the software is but apparently this game reads directly from the keyboard rather than let the software (OS?) handle it, or however that works, I'm not too sure as to where hotkeys come into play. Well, whatever, it's pretty fun given that you can get it to work with your numpad. I had to use the mouse, which is OK if you're playing on casual difficulty but if you're playing on the hardest difficulty you absolutely need to use the keyboard.\n\nOne cool part of the game is that it has actual pirates in the game (blackbeard, for instance), albeit they are only there in name and graphics, not in personality or dialogue. One annoying part of the game is that only these pirates and yourself can be considered the top ten pirates." So no random pirate can make it on the list. It really irks me
date: I think it's a terrible software design pattern to hard code the entries in the list rather than let the game evaluate the list itself. Another thing I don't like is how you're automatically set to #10 pirate of all time at the start of the game
recommended: even though you only have a handful of gold. It just makes me cringe.\n\nBut yes still fun. reviewText:

reviewText:
While my nostalgia clouds my jugdement of this game, I can really help it! This game was my childhood for so long.
Even for a game as old as it is, it has aged quite well. The game is still very fun to play and really addictive as well as haveing some really good ideas for a game that some games like it today haven't done yet.

Crew dissertion can seemly happen at random and is really annoying  when they take one of your good ships with them. You end up needing to retire and divide up the gold every few years or so to stopo them from killing you basicly.

The hand-to-hand combat could be better instead of the little cut scene stuff you get.

All in all, I would rate it:

11/10 would make every port dutch again.

reviewText:
Rating: 8/10As a huge Sid Meier fan what isn't there to love about this game? The quirkiness of the game adds a environment of fun for all ages.

Pros:	- Fast Pace Sailing
- Stright Foward Barter System
- Different countries to start from
- More or less a choose your own adventure feel.
- Ship combat is stright foward and addictive.
- The cost of the game is $10
- Great feelings of blowing up merchant and tax collecting ships.

Cons:	- The game may get borning depending on the time you wish to spend on the game.
- There is no tutorial unless you bump down the difficultly for tips during your play through.
-  The game does loose its charm after playing for a few weeks.

Conclusion:If you're a fan of Sid Meier and love Pirates then this game is a must have!

reviewText:
Pirates is a good game. That is if we look at where it is in comparison with current games. In comparison to the games that were around when this was released it was superb.

reviewText:
8/10

For however long I have been playing this game, I can give a few things that I think would be helpful to someone debating on buying this. I bought this for like $2.50 when a sale was going on. The game is DEFINITLY worth at least $10.00 though...

Goods:
-Open world partly on ship, very little on land, some forced minigame, easy UI for movement.
-Fun missions.
-You get the sense of accomplishment for doing practically anything but losing.
-Treasure maps are an entertaining game dynamic.
-Take over literally ANY ship and use it as your own.
-Raiding towns is fun.
-Player items actually make a difference in a variety of aspects of the game.

Neutrals:
-Gameplay dynamics and reward increments revolve around difficulty.
-Dancing can get more difficult as difficulties progress, and having to press 1 of 8 options in the fraction of a second based off of your partner's gestures is not very simple.
-Crew is hard to keep happy unless all you do is what pirates would do even though the game gives you the ability to be 'good'.
-Graphics match their time.
-Winds heavily effect movement around the map.
-You only retain your flagship when you give the crew members their cut.
-Some ships will not engage in ship to ship warfare and instead will follow windward right into you and force you into a cinematic minigame.
-Only about 6-8 ship upgrades.

Bads:
-Sometimes can be very repetitive.
-Sailing down certain inlets can cause the game to continually ask you if you would like to anchor.
-The Spanish own the entire south half of the Caribbean. (Not really as bad since it is pretty historically accurate. more difficult attacking vessels without upsetting the Spanish).
-When escorting another ship, another WILL spawn and attack you at some point on the voyage.

reviewText:
I got hooked on the Sid Meier's Pirates! series years ago and I was glad I was able to find this version on PC.
Aesthetically the game isn't what most people are used to seeing these days but it is an older game and is very detailed in it's artwork. The period-centric music and sounds are great and while there is no actual dialouge, the gibberish word-sounding noises characters make can be hillarious in the right scenarios. The mechanics on the PC version work a little different so if you're used to the XBOX version like I was be prepared to retrain your and when you start dancing with the governer's daughter.

It is a pirate game so you have plenty of booty and plunder to acquire as well as hidden treasures and lost cities and both sea battles and sword fight. Aside from the standard fighting and looting you find in most pirate games, Pirates! offers up trade goods to sell, daughters to be wooed and married to, and more importantly keeping your crew's morale high so you can stay at sea longer.

reviewText: I've always wanted a good pirate game, where you can recruit and manage your crew, customize your ship, terrorize the seas, and search for buried treasure.  Though this game only includes some of those features, it manages to be the best pirate game available (even better than AC: Black Flag in terms of a pure pirate experience.)  Though the visuals are simple, and some of the minigames get old quickly, this game kept me hooked for a long time.  Hopefully in the near future, we can get an updated version of this game, or another attempt at a great pirating experience that doesn't include an Animus.

reviewText: The first time I heard or played this game was when my friend let me borrow his copy for the PSP, and I loved it. Naturally, I jumped at the opportunity to own the PC edition. Along with Assassin's Creed IV, this is one of the few games out there that simulate the life of an 18th century pirate in an open-world Caribbean Sea. Though the graphics are dated and the storyline is weak (this is a Sid Meyer game, what do you expect?), the game's distinctive charm makes every boarding/treasure hunt/etc. exciting, and the swath of hidden features to find (romance, turn-based strategy, and so on) will keep you up for hours.

reviewText:
You're a pirate captain in the caribbean (you could probably roll a merchant too but that's just boring), you go do piraty things like hunt for treasure, attack boats & ships, raid cities (!), and upgrade you pirate ship (You can even name it, WOW).

There's a story or something too, but I haven't done it yet.

Pros:
- You get to be a pirate
- Treasure hunting
- Battles are simple, but enjoyable
- The duel system's fun
- You also get to be a pirate

Cons:
- Somewhat aged
- Dancing is the hardest thing ever. EVER!
- Once you have the best ship possible the game can get a little boring
- Your crew are whiney ♥♥♥♥♥es
- My saves have been corrupted a few times

Overall rating 8.6/13 Cutlasses. Good, could do with a modern remake/sequal.

reviewText:
9/10

This game is one of my favourite Sandbox Games that i've played in the last 2 years.

Your family is imprisoned by an evil Spaniard, the Marquis Montalban! By this time, you are a young boy, who manages to escape imprisonment. 18 years later, you are a fully grown man, who decides to sign up on a ship (of your choosing). You decide whether to join crew with the Spanish, the Dutch, the French, or the English. Either way, you later mutiny against your captain with nearly the rest of the crew. After defeating the captain, the crew elects you captain. You are then allowed to do whatever you wish.

Be that fighting for a certain nationality, being a Pirate and attacking everything in sight, raiding towns, attacking merchant ships, trying to rescue your long lost family, defeating the 9 best pirates in the game (Blackbeard, Henry Morgan, Stede Bonnet ETC) or just doing whatever you feel like doing.

The game may take a bit of time to get adjusted to, but in the end, the amount of enjoyment and fun you recieve from playing this is just amasing! So overal, I HIGHLY recommend getting this game, especially when its on special sale thing (like the Steam Summer Sale ETC).

reviewText:
Game of the year, every year. This game was fantastic upon it's rerelease in 2005, and it has yet to be matched. The quintessential pirate game, with the bare minimum of missing features and an exceptional amount of depth.

Want to sail around and plunder Spanish Treasure ships? Sure.

Want to find take down the 9 most notorious pirates in the Carib? Go for it.

Want to find treasure map fragments and search around distant jungles to find them? There are hundreds.

Strategy Minigame? Check. Stealth Minigame? Check. Dancing Minigame? You bet your ♥♥♥. Duelling mingame? Naturally.

This game has everything, all fine tuned and polished, not a single bug to be found. The style is timeless, casual and silly but not lacking. If you thought that AC:Black Flag had a good pirate thing going, then you need to pick this up and be blown away.

reviewText: This is basically Mount and Blade's campaign mode but instead of visceral, gory combat holding the whole thing together, we have pirate-themed quicktime event minigames. And yet, it works! I found the lack of variety pretty stunting around hour 4 though, and I doubt I'll finish it. In the ~five hours I played I completed about 10% of the actual main storyline (granted, I spent almost all that time ♥♥♥♥in' around).\n\nSo, uh, yeah. If you liked running from camp to camp, building up an army, gearing them up, then watching as they all get taken away in one ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t battle, you can do that here. Except, y'know, no battle. Pirate minigame.

reviewText: I brought my thirst and swag into a local tavern off an island I was sailing by, we proceeded to drink and dice, and having a luck roll of 77 when I was born, the gambling addict was soon out of money. He proceeded to bring me into a back room and show me this girl he had found as a stow away. Double or nothing he says for the girl as collateral, Wanting to bang out as many chicks as possible before the redcoats end my reign of terror I of course accept and walk away with a new wench. She proceeds to tell me she is looking for her husband, a naval officer who went missing, and If i was a decent man I'd help her. I proceeded to shut her down and make her train my sailors to bring morale up. A year goes by and I'm at another tavern; a man comes up to me and tells me that I own his wife and hes been looking for her all this time, would I part with her out of a sense of lost romance and love? I of course decline because this isnt a charity, he offers 10,000 gold, I accept. Its 4am and I log off, when I retern my coffers are filled with 1,000,000,000 Gold.  I proceeded to throw volley after volley of conscripted men into the meat grinder of local forts until I owned the worlds best fleet. Needless to say the game was ruined after that, but I was the best pirate in the land.

reviewText:
Duel for control of the High Seas, for the hands of noble daughters, and for the return of your stolen family. You're the hero (or is it the villain?) of Pirates!

This game hits me right in the nostalgia - it's one of the first PC games I ever really got into - and when it went on sale I couldn't resist grabbing a copy. Yes, the reused enviornments can get stale but, hey, it's an older game and what's there is solid enough to keep your interest. If you don't mind putting up with a little 'vintage realness' Pirates! is worth the money, full price or otherwise.

7/10
Would recommend

reviewText: I love this game! I have for over 20 years. Probably my favorite game in the history of video games and I wouldn't be alone in that thought. This is a remake, of a remake, of a remake. All of them are good, but I like the 1987 version for NES the best. There are minor changes in this version that I do not like or enjoy as well as the older versions. (Cartoonish graphic style, silly voice sounds, and ballroom dancing) being the main drawbacks. However it's still a great game. I wonder if it's not time for another remake of this timeless classic? With modern realistic looking graphics, expanded trading system, professional voice acting, and a darker more sinister plot and overall feel. THAT would make it AWESOME! I can only hope.

reviewText:
Really fun game if you just want to play a game where you can kick back and relax.  The controls however are wierd at first, but you'll get used to it later as you play.

Ships you want to aim for as a beginner are the ones listed below

Brigs

Frigates

Sloops

Ships you want to aim for as an expierenced player

Large Frigate(Can carry a large crew, make sure you have a big crew to board them)

Ship of the Line/Man-O-War(Only appears on higher difficulties when you cause a lot of trouble with trade routes and such, deadly firepower, avoid being hit as these deal devastating amount of damage if you do not have an armor upgrade)
-If you are feeling confident on taking them on, give it a go, you'd be a fool to sink that beast.

reviewText: I rank the 1987 version of this game as one of my favorite gaming experiences ever (eventhough it took an eternity to start on my c64 cassette-player). I've also played the 1994 version, which was more or less identical to the first, apart from then up to date grafics and sound.\nSo it was with mixed emotions that I aproached this installment of Pirates. Would it hold up, would my memories be bashed to pieces, would I be tormented by nightmares of spanish pirate hunters?\nWell I'm surprised to say that it did hold up, petty well. Most of the orginal gameplay was still there, basically the same ship combat, basically the same melee (3 attacks, 3 parries/evades), The new" stuff like added items
recommended: new city-combat all added to the gameplay in a good way
hoursPlayed: the dancing maybe not so much though. Although the grafics is now outdated

reviewText: I enjoyed this game a lot until the sword fights late game made it virtually unplayable. As your character ages you become less capable of fencing, making it tough especially because you have to sword fight in order to progress in the story. I recommend the manual (considering there is no in game tutorial) but play some games for fun before you go for the main story. I actually had quite a bit of fun joining the English and advancing to the rank of Count – ship repairs become free in your corresponding faction’s port. Seems like the Spanish have the most ports however, but it could’ve just been the luck I was having. Not a bad game, just not sure how one is supposed to beat the Mendoza guy.

reviewText: This is an oldie but a goodie.  I first played this in its final complete form during its first life cycle; Pirates! Gold (1993).  When the present game was released (2004), I was excited, though a little apprehensive.  After enjoying the old version so much 10 years earlier, would the update bring better graphics and worse gameplay, as so many updates" seem to do?\n\nIt became quickly evident that the update not only kept the outstanding gameplay of its forebear

recommended: and the freedom and sense of adventure it introduced to gaming 20-25 years ago is still experienced in playing the 2nd generation version today.\n\nPicking up this game again

reviewText: Pirates! is the all the swashbuckling fun a person could want from a pirate-themed video game without being too restrictive. It lays out a basic backstory with optional follow-through, but otherwises allows the player to run wild in the 17th Century Caribbean. At times, however, the game can be a little too hands off in terms of direction (explanation of game and world mechanics and parts of the storyline"). The controls can a little confusing at first
date: and I would really recommend a number pad if using a laptop but a mouse is a good alternative also (I've used both and found that while the mouse is more convenient a number pad makes the game much easier to play). Overall
recommended: this game is easy to get a hang of quickly and you'll have a fantastic time pirating your way across the high seas."

reviewText:
This is a remake of the original from the late 80s (was it early 90s?). It uses the same engine as civ4 and overall does a pretty nice job. You'll love it whether you've played pirates before or not.

The sea combat is great, land combat is ok, but drastically improved over the original. Duels are a tad too scripted and easy but get the job done.

The dances mini game for wooing potential mates is kind of annoying but it works ok. What doesn't work and what sucks in this game is sneaking into cities. It's a really slow stealth crawl through town and very hard to find the building you are looking for. Dreadful, just try to avoid sneaking around. As in all the other pirates games search for lost treasure at times can be really difficult but it shouldn't be too easy right?

Overall I had a great time trying to collect everything in one playthrough. It's so open ended that once you collect everything there isn't a ton of point in replaying but it does have replay value if just like the gameplay.

reviewText:
This game's features for being a pirate:
1) Rob a treasure fleet with a canoe.
2) Stumble horribly while dancing.
3) Beat an awkward hasty retreat when encountering not so fair members of the fairer sex.
4) Dig other pirates' treasures.
5) Swashbuck tavern perverts.
6) Have your crew mutiny the more famous you become.
7) The more experienced you are, the harder the game gets.

reviewText:
I enjoy this game from time to time. It's a slow paced pirate game - achingly slow when it comes to sailing (there are ways to speed it up, but even when maxed speed it's achingly slow when you sail against the wind) where you basically sack towns, fight and collect ships and more or less do what you'd expect in a game based on pirates.

The ship combat I like the most. It's all about nailing the enemy ship(s) hard enough to cripple their ability to fight back without doing so much damage that you sink them (lest you say goodbye to the loot on their ship - or the ship itself if you wanted to capture it for your fleet) all while taking into account angles and wind direction to keep your ship moving.

There are a good number of ships but once fully upgraded they fall into 2 basic catagories:
1. Big ship. Holds a lot of health, crew and cannons.
2. Small ship. Dodges everything much easier with small size, fast turning, and fast speed.

Once you collide of course there's a boarding sword fight scene - the ship battle being to widdle each others' crew down before boarding or get the other to surrender. The more crew you have the more time you have - if one crew defeats the other before the sword fight you're in is over the winning crew takes the win. There are a couple of options for swords but they don't change the experience very drastically unless on higher difficulties. After the fight the winner takes the loser's ship (they'll either sink it or add it to their fleet).

There's a few other things to the game too. Sailing and ship battles tend to take up almost all of the time I spend playing. The battles are not soul draining though - unless one ship runs and the similar speeds result in the chase going on about a literal minute or two of almost no stimulation (I prefered small fast ships because they cut out the speed problem more often than big ones). There are a few other parts though. Minigames as part of the game progression more or less; ballroom dancing with govenors' daughters to raise reputation with them, sword fighting resembles a combinarion of Paper-Rock-Scissors" and Flash Cards
date: hide and seek style treasure hunting where you collect map peices and use them to find where to go
recommended: and city seiges which feel like turn based Overhead strategy game.\n\nThe overhead city attack is actually a little fun too. Your crew make up 3 unit types. Officers
hoursPlayed: Pirates and Buckaneers. They play very simply. Officers and pirates melee attack like chess peices that all only move 1 space each on the board (with officers being stronger). The buckeneers can shoot from several spaces away for much weaker damage. Attacking from the back or sides deals a lot more. Diving into cover helps against their guns. Also the more one unit gets into a fight the weaker he is due to moral dropping. That's about it to the strategy. There are no buildings to create or making more units or anything. The enemy does have a pretty varied amount of unit types though (protip: If the enemy has horsemen go straight for a forest tile. Those suckers are OP outside of them but get cut a third of their strength in forests. If the enemy has indians get out of the forests).\n\nYou pretty much do these things over and over. There's really no plot or story other than a little intro scene (well technically you hunt down family
voteText: but it's not very focused on). It's a reletively fun game when just chilling and wanting to pimp up a ship. I won't lie though... the slow parts are painful."

reviewText:
Score: 10/10

Although Sid Meier's Pirates! is a very old game, it gives the player an unrivaled pirate experience. You are free to make your choices and shape the world in any way you see fit, and that is what I call a true RPG. Which brings us to what I believe is the strongest point of this game, the hability to provide an amazing interaction with the game world, even if you don't realized as you do, as every action brings a reaction somewhere. If you save the merchant ship from the pirates, your allies may prosper, but that very pirate ship that you sunk will be a hard hit in the pirate community. Or, if you are to become the most fiered pirate of the seas, you might find that your pillage is bringing cities to decline.
The other mechanics in the game do not present any remarkable point, but been able to have old school ship fight is quite amusing, as well as deciding your batles by your favorite method of combat (ship/sword fight). The graphics and sound are alright and there is no plot, you make your own history.
This game deserves a 10 for the great interaction mechanic it carries even being decades old! Definitely a gap to be yet filled.

reviewText:
I remember when I first played this game on the Xbox.  This is the first Sid Meier's game that I played and ever since, I was interested to try out the other Sid Meier's games.

Things I enjoyed most about this game:Sailing the Caribbean
Fighting the most notorious pirates
Plundering towns
Falling in love with the governor's daughter
Sword fighting
Finding buried treasure
Sneaking around enemy towns
Seeking revenge on the man who ruined your family
Once you play this game, you'll find it hard to stop playing.

reviewerDisplayName: I'm a geek, not a nerd
reviewText: Sid Meier's Pirates is one of his best games, alongside Civilization 4 and Civ 5. In this game you can experience the exciting world of the 18th century Caribbean, filled with notorious pirates like Blackbeard, buried treasure, and devastating storms to blow you off course. There are two basic ways you can play the game: You can plunder every single penny from every single person, or you can obey every law there is, and befriend the governor of every town and city on the map. And, of course, you can be somewhere in between. This game has one drawback I will mention: you must have a number pad on your keyboard to play it. Almost everything from sailing your ship to the swordfighting minigames requires the number pad. Aside from that limitation, it is a great game. Not too difficult, but not too easy. I recommend that you purchase this game and try it out for yourself. If you like Sid Meier's other games and you like pirates, you'll like this.

reviewText: This is one of my all time favorite games.  A great feel for pirating and lots of different styles of gameplay within it.  Large overarching quests to seek out treasures, opponents, and your family.  Then smaller pieces that make it all up:  Naval combat with a ship you customized and/or captured, dueling and dancing rhytm games, merchant trading (and looting), and even some land based army combat is an option.  The feel of the playthrough changes based on the factions you win favor with or lose, items to collect, and special crewmen to build up.

reviewText: A Fantastic game! You should really read the game manual because there is no tutorial and you have a lot of problem to find out things like: i can fire to enemy cities when iìm out of combat pressing space! Still a better game than COD:Ghost PC Version.

reviewText:
An updated edition of an older classic I loved as a kid - I was pumped to find this edition in a bundle, which I picked up for a song. Usually, this game can be found discounted, but is worth a LOT more than a lot of other, more expensive games out there.
You're a pirate, you go around capturing and looting ships, rescuing damsels in distress, dancing (it's fun; don't look at me like that), and fencing with other pirates. If you haven't tried it, DO SO.

THe only con - difficulty settings are managed in-game, unlike in previous editions, with significant in-game consequences. For some, this can be a little off-putting, especially if you want to jump straight in to a higher difficulty level from the beginning.

reviewText: For a game that's over ten years old, Pirates is easily the best game I've played in a long time.  It brings a romanticized view of a century of piracy to gaming, yet avoids Treasure Island clichés like parrots and peg legs.  You'll find a lot of light comedy in the presentation of the game, too!  However, the overall gameplay is quite sophisticated.  Unlike games such as Assassin's Creed IV: Black Flag, you have to know how to sail with the wind to your advantage.  The size of your sword, ship, and crew matter tremendously as you conquer the West Indies, as well as the hearts of colonial governors' daughters.  You may find yourself chasing ships for game days on end only to lose it to the wind, so you have to be good at assessing situations and using them to your advantage, else the enemy does the same.  Surprisingly, these elements do not detract from the gameplay, but instead add a level of interest and challenge that draws you in further.\n\nI'd give it a 9.8out of 10.  It's not perfect, but it's damn close.  My only concern is technical issues (performance), as the game did not run optimally on my system due to the game's slightly antiquated nature.  Even so, the fact that the game IS so old (and this one was a remake) stands as testament to its fantastic ability to entertain.  Any PC gamer should definitely give it a try.
voteText: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
This is one of the best pirate themed video games ever made, and the game that most pirate themed games end up taking their inspiration from. It's easy to pick up and play yet there's a lot of complexity here too. From bounties to allegiances to trading there are a lot of things you can do here yet you can also just sail around capturing ships & pillaging.

The main thing I like about this is the fact that no matter what you do you never feel bored. You never run out of stuff to do, and you're always accomplishing stuff. Goals can be challenging but they're never so impossible that they get too frustrating. This is a great title that will challenge you and even if you fail at a challenge it never punishes you for it. It gives you many chances to come back later when you're more prepared for it.

All in all one of the best games I've ever played, and certainly one of the best pirate games ever.

reviewText: I have always wanted to be a pirate, the smell of the sea, the blatant disregard for everyone around you, the pillaging, stealing, and badassary have always been something I want to partake in... However the long hours, risk of scurvy, the possible death sentence and being stuck on a boat with 100 other men for months at a time really puts a damper on that dream. This game allows you to do pretty much all that stuff without the terrible consequences! Seriously though it is a fun, light hearted, ADDICTING game that I absolutely love. It gets a bit repetitive at times but what doesn't? If you are looking for something to kill a few hours sailing the seas and pillaging every ship you come across look no further, definitely worth the couple of bucks for the amount of enjoyment you get out of it!
