reviewText:
If ye be looking fer' Pirates, you surely found them with this scurvy old title. Clean as a captain's spyglass is the play of the ships and friendly enough fer' lads and lasses of all ages ta' enjoy. Ye be starting with a measly sloop and the entire Carribean be at yer' call. Chase after ye lost family or sack some french ports and marry the Governer's daughter. Pirates be as timeless as the sea herself, an' for just 10 pieces of eight, she be right for the remembering. Yar.

Horrible attempts at pirate talk aside, this is by far one of the best games I've ever enjoyed playing. I can remember back when Sid Meier's Pirates had just been released how many endless days were spent sitting in front of my computer screen playing the wars between England and Spain. It's got a special place in my heart.

The game plays out as an open-world sandbox where one is free to pursue the noble goals of taking down the top ten most notorious pirates of the carribean and sacking ports. Or if one is feeling a bit less like fighting they can play the relatively simple merchant game of buying goods in one port and sailing them to another for profit. There is the ever present staple of pirate tales where buried treasure maps can be found. Also this portion of the game around your entire family being kidnapped and you needing to rescue them, there's that. However Pirates never directly forces you to do anything. It is a sandbox in the truest sense, at least under all of that water. Ships can be upgraded at the different ports and while learning the map comes naturally you won't be stuck going to the same 4 ports over and over (Unless you choose to, that is.)

The combat element plays out in one of four ways. The naval battles between ship and ship feel crisp and polished even despite the game's age. While rudimentery in some ways, ships bombard eachother with broadsides of roundshot, grapeshot, or chainshot. Once enough damage has been dealt or if taking the ship is the goal the ramming of the two ships together will start the swordplay. Swordplay consists of three attacks, three dodges, and one taunt. While basic it is entirely about timing and plays out fairly well. There is a turn-based strategy portion to sacking a port with a landing party but my strategy in this has always been to simply bring more men. The only place where the game falls short is in it's Stealth selection of sneaking into a hostile port. It's not bad, but it does feel a bit slow and very repetitive.

Out of all the games I've played or purchased on steam through either my own library or familyshare, this one is by far the best Game-Per-Cash value. At $9.99 it's nice to see a familiar old face pop back up and give me hours of good natured fun. I can't reccomend it enough.

reviewText:
Sid Meier has made many games with clever tactical depth, but is not so swollen with rules, so that anybody can jump right in. Pirates! continues the tradition by being a game chock full of strategy, but is highly accessible.

The game is a sandbox. You can go anywhere, and do anything, within the Spanish Main. Generally, you plunder ships or towns, and get promoted by friendly nations. There are plenty of other things to do, too.
Tasks you perform have an associated action oriented mini-game. You'll be ship-to-ship battling and swordfighting a lot. I like most of these games, though your mileage may vary. Many people have mixed feelings about them.

As far as management goes, the game cuts out micro-managing. The action just keeps flowing. The typical mundane busy work of hard-core strategy games is kindly removed here, in order to get to the good bits. There are plenty of strategic decisions to be made, but you get to think in a sense of what you WANT to do, not what you HAVE to do.

Certain things are a little tricky to get used to. Sailing East is much harder than sailing West. Your crew slowly becomes restless over time, forcing you to pay them off and take a few months vacation before going back to sailing.

After you get to the ripe old age of about 35, your health starts to decline, and you might have to retire before too long. This takes you to an amusing detailed report on your post-pirate life. Hopefully you are a Governor instead of a Pauper!

The graphics and sound are cartoony. Everything looks like it's from a Disney/Pixar movie, and the voice acting is done in jibberish, like in The Sims. Subtitles are in English, though. The cartoony feel is not bad, but is sometimes just a little TOO campy.

The controls are a bit strange. While you can use a mouse, you're better off doing the mini-games using the numpad. It's a little awkward at first, but you get used to it fairly soon.

Pirates! is one of my all time favorite games. Two thumbs and a wooden peg-leg up!

reviewText:
This game is like 5 games in one: sailing, real time ship battles, fencing, turn based strategy, dancing (Rhythm game), and more. Stick with me here though: what makes classic nintendo games great, is that they are simple enough for a newbie to pick up and enjoy but also evolving with enough depth to grasp a hardcore gamer. THIS IS THAT TYPE OF GAME and what makes Pirates! so great as well. Start out as an apprentice -each time your crew is unhappy, divide the plunder to start refresh and jump to the next diffculty level. The game really progresses from each tier of diffculty nicely til your at the most difficult level and you are like wow, how did this game get to this point, it was so easy at first.

The graphics still hold up too!

Play this now! Trust me, there is something for everyone in this game.

reviewText:
So basically this is a pirate simulator. You start out as a young guy with a small crew and ship. Years ago an evil pirate breaks up your family leaving you alone and now you're matured you set out on the Caribbean. From there you choose to follow the storyline of getting your family back OR disregard that and lead the life of a stereotypical pirate.

Gameplay is a little limited BUT there's a lot of paths you can go. By paths I mean you can choose which time period to live in, choose what life you want to lead, choose whom you ally with (or be a total pirate), a great selection of ships (all customizeable), your personal skill sets. The limited part is that for most of the time you'll be doing the same thing: get a  ship, go plunder other ships, sell items, get gold, talk to people in the town. There's some side things like rescuing people, helping a country out, collecting treasure maps but generally it's the same thing regardless of which path you go.

The visuals are very colourful and beautiful. Although the game is old the visuals have a style that still looks good and not dated. The sound is great. The music, although limited to a few key tunes, is very pirate styled and pleasing.

So in short although the game is somewhat limited in what you can do it doesn't get boring over time! That's because it is quite immersive, aesthetic, controls well and is just fun! Beautiful graphics and audio and good controls ensure this game doesn't feel dated.

7/10

reviewText: When I first picked this game up from the Sid Meier Humble Bundle I looked at it with nothing but a slight idea of what was to come.  To be honest I didn't expect much at first but after getting into the game after an hour or so, I was hooked.  The game is simple in nature yet complex to master, as are many of Sid Meier's games.  The pirates theme is masterfully directed and the story, while lacking, doesn't need to be there in the first place.  You create your own story.  Become the most vile Pirate to ever sail the seven seas or be a noble sailor for one of the nations colonizing the area.  Seek revenge solely on those who took your family or loot and plunder everywhere and everyone.  This game is a masterpiece in every sense of the word.  Though it may be a bit clunky and awkward at points, it adds to the charm of the game.  I can not reccomend this game enough to anyone with interest in the pirate theme or anyone looking for a fun adventure.

reviewText:
Sid Meier's Pirates another great game from a great game maker. Your family is taken for ransom, you grow to be a teenager and you are ready to set sail to try to free your enslaved family from the evil Colonel.

Or you can say SCREW THAT, IMA GO PLUNDER SOME SHIPS!!! You are free to do so :)

This is a pirate-sandbox game. Similar to the newly released Pirate Game, Assassin's Creed IV: Black Flag. You can follow the storyline and set free your enslaved family, or you could go out to sea and plunder, get yourself married to a governer's daughter, gather the ships of Blackbeard, Black Bart, and Captain Morgan, upgrade them to their highest, THEN go out and rescue them. This is what I like about Sid Meier's games, its got good sandbox engine to it. The Carribean is HUGE, you could sail for hours and maybe not even get 100% of the content done.

The Melee combat is fluid, but a little TOO easy. Just counter when the button flashes, then attack. The ship combat is fun as well, although its very trivial if compared to Black Flag. If you wish to go save your family and THEN take down famous pirates, feel free to do so! It is important to note that you should not split your loot until you feel you are ready to do so, because you will lose some ships and loot and you need all the loot you can get since upgrades and items are expensive, but it makes it so money HAS a use at least. Unlike Black Flag, this game requires you make an effort to keep your ship in good condition and your crew happy, if your crew gets unhappy, they will abandon you. You dont want that.

As I said, the Carribean is huge, but honestly in this game, Its kind of TOO big. Black Flag has a function where you can initiate Travel Speed and get where you need to go faster. This game only has half and full sails, and even then, if you dont follow the wind direction, your not gonna get anywhere in the next 5-10 minutes. It should also be worth mentioning that you do NOT have any sort of waypoint system in this game. You have to navigate your way around, which can be a bit difficult, but if your patient, you'll start getting it.

So, is this game good? Yes! This is for you if you absolutely love the Golden Age of Piracy and want to experience it in a way.

reviewText:
Sid Meier's Pirates! is a surprisingly fun and deep simulation of being a ship captain in the Caribbean during the glory days of piracy. You're not limited to being a pirate. Although the game doesn't explicitly say so, the simulation of the four major powers and two minor powers operating in the Caribbean is quite complex. There's a real war going on, and all of it happens by sea. Although invasions happen over land, troops don't get into position to invade unless they're transported by ship. Many troops don't get paid and people don't get fed unless their wages and food arrive by sea. The economy is primarily based on sea trade, and blockades occur. Warships must be built and sailed where they're needed. And governors and other important people move around by ship.

All this means that there's a rich environment for you to play in, and many possibilities for how you want to play. You can, of course, be a pirate and loot the treasure ships of all the wealthy nations. You can serve a nation as a legitimate but independent privateer. You can pretend to be part of a nation's navy and go to war on its behalf, attacking targets of military importance and earning the appreciation of the nation even if you don't get much money out of it. You can even take part in land-based invasions and try to conquer cities, either for the benefit of a nation - territory really changes hands in this game - or just to loot and pillage. Or you can be a peaceful trader. The lesser powers, pirates and Indians (i.e. Native Americans), have their own agendas which enrich the environment further.

Besides the sandbox gameplay, you have several concrete goals: rescue your family, acquire wealth and fame, woo beautiful women, find hidden treasure and lost cities, bring villains to justice, and defeat the top pirates in the Caribbean. There are also minor quests that allow you to act as a law enforcer (or turn a blind eye to crime in exchange for bribes, if you wish), and mini-games such as breaking into enemy towns, dancing (which is quite fun), and both real-time combat at sea and turn-based combat on land.

There's a lot to do, and for the most part it's all well-designed. There are five difficulty levels, allowing the game to be enjoyable for all players, and several eras you can start in and skills you can specialize in, which increase replay value. The game's main shortcoming is that it's too easy, because it helpfully auto-saves before anything bad happens, allowing you to simply reload your game and retry. This diminishes the importance of many gameplay elements, such as breaking out of jail, upgrading your character, and maintaining multiple ships in your fleet, and leads to excessive risk-taking while dampening the thrill of success. The game really needs an Iron Man mode. (Thankfully, a mod to add one exists.)

Another potential problem for some players is that the game doesn't have much of a tutorial, but the manual is good and worth reading.

reviewText:
I still remember the first Pirates! It was a very good game to play at that time and i spent a lot of hours in it. So when this version came available i hoped it was as the first one and it was. It is a remake of the original with better graphics, playability and they added a few extra's to the newer version. If you are a fan of the old one then this is a must have, relive your childhood.

If you are looking for a realistic sea battle game then this is not the game you are looking for it is a casual game.


Con's
- User controls are somewhat unusual. Takes a few to get used to but not a real hinderance.

Pro's
- Different activities to pursue. Be a trader, Pirate or go out and conquer for your nation.
- Easy battles which makes it fun to play, it does not take ages to conquer a ship or town.

reviewText:
This game has everything.

Ship Combat, Tactical Strategy, Romance, Stealth, Economy, Politics, Dancing and Fencing!

You can choose to be a nice guy and only send cannonballs towards pirate ships, or send it towards everyone. Different ships have different cargoes, and you might want to capture some for your own fleet.

You have different difficulties, different times (1600-1660) to choose from. As your character ages, his health deteriorates and in the end you retire.

I recommend reading the manual though, as the game has no tutorial and drops you smack-dab in the middle of the caribbean between four rival factions,

reviewText: This is a great classic. Each successive journey out into the world gives you the opportunity to build your wealth up through attacking ships, raiding towns, finding treasure or just the best buy/sell prices. The higher you set the difficulty, the more loot you get to keep. The fewer crew you have, the more loot there is to go around. So there's a real incentive to keep challenging yourself to take on more risks.\n\nFreeform Pirate games aren't common, but this is definitely one of the best.

reviewText: A graphically enhanced, feature-enriched, compatability-stabalized version of a completely addictive game, that set the standard for ALL subsequen open-world pirate games!  You don't have to be a fan of the original to thoroughly enjoy all this game has to offer.  Sid Meier understood what gamers want out of the gaming experience.  This polished classic is sure to delight ALL audiences, even those who are new to the pirate-genre of gaming.  Whether you choose the route of a pirate, or a privateer in the service of a great navy, you are going to have fun!

reviewText: This is a great classic. Each successive journey out into the world gives you the opportunity to build your wealth up through attacking ships, raiding towns, finding treasure or just the best buy/sell prices. The higher you set the difficulty, the more loot you get to keep. The fewer crew you have, the more loot there is to go around. So there's a real incentive to keep challenging yourself to take on more risks.\n\nFreeform Pirate games aren't common, but this is definitely one of the best.

reviewText:
Basically Mount & Blade but with Pirates and story (A pathetic story, but it's there).
Treasure hunting, sailing, trading, ship to ship and sword combat (realtime), raiding towns (turn based).
Only downsides I can see are the mutiny mechanic (there's a sort of upkeep system that makes you keep stealing amounts on a regular basis and they get increasingly picky about how you get it) and the aging of the captain (It's a decent length though. My first campaign is still going).
If you want a time sink, this is a good one to go with.

reviewText:
Get this game.

Get it, right now. It's only $10.

This is a remake of an absolute classic of a game. You play as a pirate/privateer, sailing around the Carribean. You have abolute freedom of action. Capture Spanish treasure galleons? Loot cities by land battles? Sail whatever ship you can get your hands on that suits your playstyle, from fast light yacht-things to enormous slow galleons bristling with guns.

You sail your ship around the Carribean, using the wind to get around. When you attack ships, you play the ship fighting" minigame. When you board an enemy ship
date: it switches to the "swordfighting" minigame.\n\nThe polish that went into this is enormous. The minigames are fun and engaging
recommended: and seamlessly tied together by a greater scope and context. You want to win that swordfight because you'll capture that fat merchant ship full of loot
hoursPlayed: not because the game says "ok
voteText: this next bit is a swordfight".\n\nThey don't make 'em like they used to. They used to make 'em like this. GET IT!"

reviewText:
SUMMARY : Unlikely, but Fun, Adventure/Strategy Game.
PRO's : Bright, clear, cartoon style graphics. Humerous without negatively impacting the gameplay or tone. Strong Replay Value. Informative and well documented PirateOPedia (ie the Help/Background System). Should be playable by most systems.
CON's : Can run a little quick for controll by mouse only, highly recommend a keyboard-mouse combo. NO STEAM ACHIEVEMENTS.
NOTES : The PC version is more complete than other versions.

SINGLE PLAYER RATING : 3.5 STAR.
FRIENDS CO-OP RATING : NOT APPLICABLE.
ONLINE CO-OP RATING : NOT APPLICABLE.
MULTIPLAYER : NOT APPLICABLE.

reviewText: Sid Meier's Pirates! is a 2005 remake of the original game he made back in the 1980s. This time, you have better graphics, more advanced swordfighting sequences and more options for everything. You start the game off by leading a mutiny on a merchant vessel. From there on, you can decide whether you want to avenge your family by defeating the Marquis de Montalban, defeating all the major pirate captains in the Spanish Main, accumulate vast amounts of wealth through trade, marry a governor's daughter whether she be sexy or ugly, or if you want to attack merchant ships, plunder seaports and instigate a brand new war. The choice is yours! My only complaint is that you can't customize your character: although he does age, you always have to be the Orlando Bloom type of character. Beyond that, this game is every sandbox adventure you ever dreamed of.

reviewText: My second favorite pirate game of all time.  Favorite being Uncharted Waters: New Horizons on the SNES.  This game is entirely based in the Carribean.  Starting the game up you choose what type of pirate you are going to be by picking a skill.  After that you pick your nationality.  You can choose between Spanish, English, French, and Dutch.  The Spanish seem to have the most ports and cities so I'd consider them the easiest to start with.  You work your way up the pirate ranks by finding buried treasure, defeating notorious pirates like Blackbeard, and trading goods between ports.  It's a great game and worth the price in my opinion.

I've also played the 1994 version, which was more or less identical to the first, apart from then up to date grafics and sound.\nSo it was with mixed emotions that I aproached this installment of Pirates. reviewText: Where to start..... Unlike alot of these reviewers, i had not played this before, i walked into this game completely blind. So, the fact that theres no nostaligia involved here, my review is for those who have never played or heard of this game before. Theres no tutorial or manual to speak of, but to be honest this game dosnt really need one. Its an rpg, so if youve palyed previous rpgs like me, you'll have a basic understanding of what your doing. If you havnt played one before then this would be an excellent first choice. So, your thrust into this open world pirate game with nothing but a back story, which i might add is not narrated in the slightest. In fact, i think the reason theres so much content in this game is because they didnt do any voice acting AT ALL. Theres just mostly grunts or the wooing of ladies for dialog". reviewText: This is a terrificly fun, low stress game that gives you the sights and sounds of being a pirate in the caribbean seas circa the 1600's. It plays out like a fast paced board game crossed with an enthusiastic child's fanciful imaginings of the piratey life: all of the highs and none of the lows. It's such a breath of fresh air to play a game that doesn't try to saddle you with a heavy Hollywood" cinematic story. The encounters are entirely under your control in true sandbox style and you venture through a series of minigames at different locations to obtain information about the placement of notable people
hoursPlayed: with each task being fun and easy to grasp.  There's a wealth of things to do with the only drawback being repetition sets in too early; you fight the same pirates

reviewText:
(This is the 2004 remake of the original game from 1987).

Sid Meier's Pirates is a lighthearted swashbuckling romp set during the Age of Discovery.

The gameplay basically boils down to a series of minigames; ship-to-ship battles, sword duels, dancing, land battles and treasure hunts.

The game is open-ended; there's a 'main quest' of sorts but you can feel free to ignore it if you want. There's plenty of other goals to pursue; find buried treasure, defeat infamous pirates to become the most feared in the Caribbean, track down wanted criminals and collect their bounties, escort ships carrying peace treaties (or betray the nation you're helping and destroy them - war is more profitable than peace for a pirate after all) or just attack everything in sight and amass as much loot as you can.

A game won't last forever - your pirate starts the game aged 18 and as time passes in the game he will age and eventually be forced into retirement. If this game has an overall goal" at all it's to have the highest score you can at the time you retire.

The game has difficulty levels; on every playthrough after your first you can choose between them - first time starting a new game
date: you're forced into the easiest difficulty
recommended: though there's a way to change it once you get going
hoursPlayed: too.\n\nUnfortunately
voteText: I don't feel like the game has much replay value. The minigames (with the exception of ship battles) are repetitive and shallow and I was burned out on the game before I'd seen everything it had to offer (I completed the "main quest"
helpfulPercent: went after all the named pirates and then lost interest). The harder difficulty settings feel more frustrating than genuinely challenging
votesTotal: I got 25 hours of fun out of this game for £6
votesFunny: so I'd say I got my money's worth; I recommend it.\n\n"

reviewText:
A classic. One of my favorite games of all time.Personal overall rating: 9/10

I've played this game for almost 9 years now! Just got it on my computer a few days ago and, wow... It's so much better. I first played it on Xbox, then psp, then got it for my 360, and now have it for my computer. Of course, this is the best version of the game. ALL HAIL THE MASTER RACE

OPTIONS MENU:
The Video settings has 9 options. Picture Gamma, Water Detail, Object Detail, World Detail, Resolution, Shadows, Advanced Lighting, Trillinear Filtering, & Shaders. It's an old game, most computers will be able to handle it with the settings turned up relatively high.
The Audio Settings has a Master Volume slider, Music Volume, Sound FX Volume, Dance Music Volume, and a 3D Sound Driver toggle.
The Modify Ship's Sails and Flags option changes your ship's flag appearance and the logo/crest on your main sail. There's 6 crests/logos for your sail. 1.Dutch: Greater Coat of Arms of The Netherlands, 2.English: St George Crest, 3.French: Royal Coat of Arms of The Kingdom of France, 4.Indians: Tribal Tiki Logo, 5.Pirates: Jolly Roger Crest, 6.Spanish: Coat of Arms of Toledo.
There are 5 flags, the Flags are 1.Dutch: Orange flag with a green xing emblem, 2.English: White flag with a red St George cross, 3.French: Blue flag with a gold Flour De Les emblem. 4.Pirates: Black flag with a white Jolly Roger. 5.Spanish: Yellow flag with a black Royal Lion.

GRAPHICS:
It's an old game. It's not exactly pretty. The game looks best while you're out sailing. There is noticeable aliasing, mushy textures, and choppy animations. The water refelction is decent. The explosion effect during ship battles when cannonballs make contact and when ships explode is awesome. It's the game's strongest point graphically. The way the colors of the sea blend together is nice as well.

STORY:
The story is kind of weird. An evil Spanish nobleman (the Marquis de la Montalbán) interupts a dinner party consisting of you and your family. Your family is in debt to him. When you see him, you immediatley know he has bad intentions, so you bolt passed him through the door. He takes your family. They become slaves. You survive on your own for the next 10 years. You begin your young adulthood joining a faction (Dutch, English, French, or Spanish). You serve on a ship where a cruel captain is in charge. Tired of being abused and insulted by the captain, you and your mates rally up and form a mutiny against him. You boot him from the ship, and take charge. You're the captain now, and realize this is the perfect opportunity to find your lost family.

PLAYING THE GAME:
Sailing is a ton of fun. The feeling of adventure you get from cruising the sea is so satisfying. Playing a game that isn't the same copy paste recipe as every other game in itself is extremely satisfying. There's open sea adventure, epic ship battles, duels, city invasions, sneaking through hostile towns, treasure hunting, pirate hunting, and the wonderful ability to do whatever you want. Live the pirate life your way. You can gain new items for your character like dual pistols and some well crafted swords. You can aquire new ships and give them upgrades. You can even name your ships as well as your character of course. You'll be addressed by your character's name by the other people in the game. They address you by your surname, so when creating your character make sure you name them by their last name. Anyways but yea, that's the game. You build up your crew, and become the deadliest pirate to ever live.

Please try the game. It's cheap, it's fun. You'll enjoy it. Please just try it. Yea it has it's flaws, but for what it is it's pretty much perfect.

reviewText:
My wife and I love this game so much we decided to make a let's play - who knew a game this old could still keep us hooked after all these years?   I love this game, my wife loves it, my kids love it, even my father in law played for hundreds of ours.  It's appropriate - and fun- for all ages.

The combat is simplified, easy and very satisfying - the story is simple and satisfying, the graphics are still beautiful and compare to many modern indie games out there.  Actually now that I think of it, this was one of the first non dungeon rogue like games to come out.  Every game is different and you never know where the seas will take you.

Highly recommended and we'd love to connect with other Sid Meier's Pirates players out there!
Here is my wife and I playing what we call a thirty minute pirate game
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=NBZzpCnTo3w

reviewText:
I really had my reservations about this game. It looked a little dated, and not much content. I do like ships and pirates and trading and after I got the game in a humble bundle i decided id give it a go. This game is wonderful. You start out as an apprentice level sailor with the que's flashing during fights and dances so you dont fail. Then journeyman comes around and the que's are gone and you have to see the movement of the person your fighting or dancing with to have an idea of what your defence/dance move should be.

At first i thought it was dumb that you could only battle one ship, but that ship you have direct control over and it would be difficult to control more, and relying on AI to fight with you brings in risks of ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ decisions.

Over all, this game is really worth it. i would have paid the 10 bucks in full if i knew what i was getting into

reviewText:
An amazing game that needs a sequel, or yet another remake. Personally I say Remake.

In anycase, you sail around shooting cannons, sword fighting, plundering cities and searching for treasure, or your long lost family members.

The real prize of this game is to capture the famed 'Ship of the Line' which is the fastest ship and carrying the largest amount of cannons at 48. I'm hopeful for a remake of this game one day, in the mean time this game will keep your pirate needs satisfied.

reviewText:
Let me start off by saying that I love this game so much that I almost felt like I was cheating on my wife when I bought it anew last night. I bought it on the day that it originally came out, and spent actual DAYS playing the game, only stopping to eat, bathe, and go to the bathroom. I don't think that I slept more than eight total hours in that first week, and my name was known, loved, and feared throughout the Caribbean. More so than in any other Sid Meier game before or since, I was completely engulfed by this game to the point of addiction.

Then, you know, life (and other games) happened.

So, flash forward a few years and I saw that it was on Steam. How well did it hold up? Would I fire it up, laugh at the dated gfx and gameplay, never to play again? Would it be like I'd never stopped playing and find myself engulfed into the game again?

I downloaded it last night, and have already racked up seven, almost eight hours. Gfx and some clunky and (now) counter-intuitive gameplay aside, I still love this game and thought it was absolutely worth the $10 to buy it again. It's just as fun as I remembered, although I do confess that I still hate the dancing portion of the game! Absolutely recommended!

My only REAL gripe is with the sound. It's not that it's dated, it's just that when you're playing the game, you have no choice but to either turn off the sound altogether OR you're forced to listen to the same... jaunty... pirate... ditties... again... and... again... and... Imagine being forced to listen to the sound of a dentist's drill or your favorite child's death rattle on infinite loop - this is the quality of the music. While you can go into the system properties and turn off the music, that's only the music for cut scenes and the like - the in-game music is tied irrevokably to the sound effects, so no cannonfire, no sound of the wind... unless you're willing to listen to monkey-grinder music.

Arrr me maties! To this date the best game for you to become the most badass pirate ever! Beautiful sandbox-like gameplay, a true gem, sadly overlooked by many people. I really don't have much to criticize - perhaps the lack of a proper story. But what the game has to offer (which is sailing around with ships, battling others, duels, sieging cities and many other things) is really good.

And unlike Assassins Creed 4, there is actually kinda realistic morale element where your crew can revolt when you're too long at sea, or you're not very succesful pirate. Game itself is easy to jump in, but certainly provides more than a decent challenge.

Ship ahoy!

reviewText: Why is this game so good? If you look at it from an objective PoV, this is just a collection of repetitive minigames (there's a swordfighting, which is basically a rythm game; Dancing, which is literally a rythm game; Theres a siege which has some strategical options but basically coes down to more troops win"; And a naval battle which becomes somewhat boring as you realize the AI is really dumb at it). On the top of it all is a fairly simple resource management system (basically
date: have food) and "get from point A to point B" system which is a slog
recommended: especially if you are travelling from west to east.\nThis doesnt sound too good now
hoursPlayed: does it.\n\nSo why is this game so good? I played the heck out of the original about 20 years ago on a Commodore64
voteText: and again about 10 years ago when this version came out.\nAnd yesterday I bought the Steam version and I just wanted to fire it up for a while to see how it runs
helpfulPercent: and then somehow I played almost 8 hours straight without even moving from my chair or noticing the time.\nDuring that 8 hours
votesHelpful:
I
- raided countless ships
- Always showed mercy to the lads who wanted to come aboard
- became the most notorious pirate on the entire spanish main
- Found Blackbeard's legendary buried treasure between a tree with a dead man hanging and an Inca temple
- Sacked Havana twice
- elected a dutch govenor there
- Found out the new govenor's daughter is actually beautiful
- became pretty good at pressing buttons while dancing
- I fenced with her fincée
- Then I rescued her from captivity
- and married her (which turned out was a pretty bad idea since traveling from Havana to anywhere is actually a slugfest)
- I found two of my long- lost relatives
- kicked the ♥♥♥♥ of Evil Baron Raymondo a dozen times
- defeated the long-standing enemy of my family Marquis Montalban (who is now my cabin boy)
- and found the legendary lost city of the Incas.

So there you have it. I think the strongpoints of the game is the athmosphere

reviewText:
When Sid Meier's Pirates! came out in 2005 it was a great remake and a great game by itself.

However, i cannot recommend it anymore. The graphics are still not too shabby and the game itself is great but you cannot select widescreen resolutions in the menu and so you will end up with a 4:3 windowed game.
Even worse is that the game somehow disables numpad on startup. As a result(?) the keys won't work altough the game is relying on numpad for controls heavily.

I would really like to see the developers adding widescreen resolutions and real Windows 7/8/10 compatibility and a fix for the numpad problem. Up until then the 1987 PIRATES! GOLD will work with less hassle than this game.

reviewText:
An old game with old game problems.
Some minor bugs with Steam and DirectX that can be easily fixed.
The main problem is the lack os native widescreen support. There is a couple of fixes available, but if you apply any of them, the HUD, some buttons and texts stays partially off screen. If that isn't bad enough, to click on some buttons you'll need to click outside then for them to work. It gets very frustrating to play this way.
If you don't apply the resolution fix, you get stuck with 4:3 aspect ratio resolutions and using this with widescreen, everything will get stretched.

reviewText:
I bought this game on sale as I was looking through the lunar sale offers and came across it.
From my childhood I remember my dad playing this as I watched and he recently told me he started playing it again. I bought it and while I don't regret my purchase, I can't recommend it either. For the time it was released, this was an awesome game.
Now...
Widescreen resolutions makes the game crash on Windows 10 and when I tried buying a diamond necklace at the tavern, it crashed again for some reason, even though I've bought anything else I've come across without issues.

Maybe it's meant to be that way, but the dancing minigame is horrible, every guide says to follow the rythm of the music, but even as I press the required key, I lose my progress if I had any. Only thing that works is to press slightly after you'd think it would fit with the music and the rythm, but this is just making it incredibly hard to time right.

If you've played this game before,you won't need my review, if you haven't, don't buy it. It's outdated and crashy on newer systems.

reviewText: Though I put quite a few hours into this game my lasting impression is that it's not very enjoyable.  The concept itself is good, but the game becomes very repetitive and the play balance on harder difficulties is completely bonkers.  Late game on Rogue difficulty I lost a ship to only three hits, when fighting other ships of the same type I would hit them twenty times or more before they would sink.  The AI gets special abilities like attacking you on the strategic map, and the late quests" of endgame are simply finding and fighting the same guy over and over again until you get a map to go and fight him again in some place in the middle of no where.\n\nAnd while the game has a lot of "mini-games"
date: man of these are simply not compelling.   The game has a lot of content but all that content is ultimately light on depth
recommended: and despite playing the game to its conclusion and getting a Fame score of 106 my "victory" was little more than a page of text.  Why not a simple cinematic?\n\nIf you get it cheap
hoursPlayed: play it
voteText: then go on to something with more enduring quality and depth."

reviewText: I heard so much about this game and I love Civilization that I had to try it.  It was meh.  I think nostalgia clouds too many minds on how wonderful this game is.  It's not bad, it just isn't all that special. There isn't a real storyline (they kind of make a basic quest of finding your family which isn't very exciting) and maybe that would have spiced the game up for me.  I love a good story.  It just throws you in there and you just start living the life of a pirate captain which is great if you don't like being shackled to linear game play.  Felt like a chore going back and forth on the map at a snail's pace and I just wasn't having fun.  I gave up after realizing how many times I had to trek back and forth and I didn't want to waste my time with it.  I feel like this would work as a casual game on a mobile device that you could play for a bit, put it down, and pick it up later.  The dancing sequences are annoying, the sword fights are all the same and get boring, and trying to catch the wind in your sails was ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ me off.  I feel there are more engaging choices out there.

reviewText: Ugh, so much abou this game drives me CRAZY, but so much of it is fun too. The fun part is mostly due to open-world sandbox play, with no scripted gameplay, you can just sail around and do what you want. The good is pretty good. The bad is absolutely a deal breaker, though. The dancing thing with the governor daughter is impossible on the PC. I played this to death on the Xbox with no problems but this stupid PC version gives you 1/10th of a second to respond to the dancing bullcrap which made that part of the game unbelievably frustrating--on par with the buggy SM Railroads. The ships get stuck on land masses and LAUNCH like a rocket out of ports so you have to hit pause every time you leave a port. ANNOYING! In summary, it's too buggy and annoying for repeat play. the old Xbox version of possibly iPad version are better choices for this game. This PC original is not worth playing.

reviewText: I wish ratings was not yes or no. Im giving it a no just because the ratings are too high. See, it is a great game for its time. But theres a few annoying parts. It cant be called an adventure game because you are restricted to the caribean and you do not feel like an adventurer. Not the improved 'uncharted waters' I hoped for. The challenge is too wimpy at first- get your attack speed up and mash buttons in duels to win every battle- then becomes too hard. But most annoying of all there is no tutorials. I have played this long and became #1 pirate, and dont know HTF dueling (the main thing in the game) even works, the controlls seem to suck. Dancing seemed impossibly hard. Granted I am playing as adventurer captain (hard difficulty) but that stuff should have been explained by the time I finished my 6th pirating carreer. You cant really customize your ship. And trading stinks, you really cant make any money at it. For the record I do recommend it anyways if it is on sale.\nSome things I find quite great is the ship to ship battles take a lot of skill, and has quite a lot of depth. And when you attack a town the game turns into a nearly full strategy game.\nIf I or anyone else could mod the game for even a few months, it would be great. But as is it just slightly below wonderfull, just a collectors item from another time.

reviewText:
So much promise but age and/or operating systems have brought down what Pirates could be.

The first problem I encountered was an absolutely ridiculous graphical glitch with the sails and flags of the ships. I would boil it down to a physx issue, but I don’t think that technology even existed when Pirates was released. Basically what would happen is that when the wind blew a certain direction, any fabric on screen would stretch to infinity and obscure 60-70% of the screen. The next issue I had was that for some reason the primary method of control (awkwardly using the number pad) straight up did not work. I tried a different keyboard as well as an old PS2 board and neither allowed any of the diagonal buttons to register.

I’m not a computer genius or anything, but I can’t imagine all the technical problems I had running the game being anything more than driver issues and modern operating system changes. If you have an older XP system I bet this game is amazing, from the little bit I suffered through, there was so much awesome content. But if you own a modern gaming computer, just be aware that this game may not play nice with your setup.
voteText: 11 of 57 people (19%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Maybe I don't get this game, or it just wasn't running properly on my computer.
A slow and choppy game, Pirates is a baisc open world Pirate game where you sail around trading and plundering.

The trade mechanic worked fairly identically to most games with a trade mechanic, and was fine, but the actual pirate battles were fairly lackluster, mostly involving a bit of maneuvering and a whole lot of patience. While you can build up a fleet of ships, this is mostly for maximizing your cargo capacity, and not really for getting increases in combat bonuses (at least as far as I could tell). You can only ever bring one ship into battle, which kept the gameplay very light. If there is depth to be found in this game, I was too frustruated by the incredibly slow pacing to find it.

reviewText: It's not that this is an old game, it's that this game isn't very good.  Gameplay is instantly repetitive and dull, very little risk, all reward, but no real action.  Sea battles make no sense, guns don't matter, all you do is ram the ship, hit a few buttons to defeat the captain, loot.  Dancing with girls mini game is just silly.  Mechanics make no sense.  Split loot disbands your fleet and you lose all your money?  Why would you ever do that?  Retire ends the game?  Why would you ever do that?  No clear benefits to upgrading ships, again because all you do is ram other ships and duel.  No clear point to hiring more men, just more mouths to feed for no reason.  Overall, just a terrible game that you throw away after half an hour.

reviewText:
Played it way back when Blockbuster was still around on the original Xbox. It's aged, but still a very enjoyable experience.

Graphics: 7/10 - Held up better than I would've expected.
Gameplay: 8.5/10 - Solid ship battle mechanics, reaction-based swordplay, ship management, and even mutiny.
Sound: 8/10 - Would've been an 8.5 or 9 but for whatever reason I still don't particularly like the ballroom tracks.
Lasting Appeal: 9.5/10 - There are so many ways to play this game that you'll find yourself making new saves just to experience everything this game throws at you.

Overall: 8/10 - One of my favorite original Xbox games.

reviewText: This game is great. In fact, it's probably one of the most fun games I've ever played. You get to live the fantasy of being a pirate...not with all the realities of wasting months of your life on the sea and all the infections that come with that, but you get to fire cannons and have sword fights on deck and raid colonial fortresses and dance with the governors' beautiful daughters. There is plenty of variety in what you can do in this game. If you're tired of capturing ships for profit, go take an outpost for your favorite nation; search for buried treasure; play the main story line; hunt down famous pirates; get captured just so you can have fun sneaking out of jail. This game never gets boring, and the difficulty levels are sufficient to either give you a leisurely stroll through the Caribbean or a truly gripping fight at sea. Highly recommend it.

reviewText:
Stupidly fun pirates game. There's a main quest to follow, but you can ignore it if you'd like. There are lost cities to discover, treasure to be unburied, towns to be sacked! Work your way up to the number 1 pirate by defeating famous pirates (including Blackbeard!). It's a game of revenge and adventuring, but even a taste of romance as you dance your way through all the governor's daughters. Literally dancing, because there's a dancing minigame.

One thing I particularly enjoyed about this game was the combination of real-time and turn-based strategy. Most of it's real-time, but oftentimes if you sack a town, you'll have to pit your pirates against their soldiers in a fun turn-based game (the only time that isn't the case is if your number of pirate greatly trumps their number of soldiers; then you'll just have a sword fight with the Captain of the Guards).

It's a fun game with several levels of difficulty, plus you can start at different time periods, which will also help decrease or increase the difficulty of the game, so replayability is high.

reviewText: In this game you take a role of privateer or pirate. You can work for either English, French, Dutch or Spanish - or even for all of them if you time your actions well. There's constantly changing basic economic and political system where player's actions do affect on the bigger picture as well. You can sail, capture ships, fight pirates, trade, do missions, dance with governors daughters and so on. There's many goals to fullfill and many ways to play. Because there's different eras to choose from and the world is open, dynamic and reactive the gaming experience does change lot. There's also different difficulty levels which do have effect. Game's replayability value is quite high and you can get it cheaply, especially on sale.\n\nTechnically speaking I have been playing this game for something like 30 years from it's early versions on Commodore 64. From those early days they have added more content and huge haul in graphics but the core is same. And it works. Still one of the best, if not best, pirate games there are.

reviewText:
Just picture it- Your flagship, a host of galleon's stuffed with spice and sugar, each pirated by a skeleton crew under the watchful eye of your Frigate 'Banshee'. From the aft deck, you stand, uniform tugged by the breeze, gazing back at the spanish main. It's cities burn as people dig through the ashes or else cower under the new governor's you've appointed whom now reign over the new dominions of your country. A great host of men have gathered beneath you, grumbling about being packed like sardines in their triple hammocks but still, eagerly awaiting their share of over one hundred thousand in newly minted Spanish doubloon's. The Spanish, whose military has so spectacularly failed to halt your onslaught now watch in disarray for the dark smudge of smoke on the horizon, a precursor, heralding the terror to come. For the greatest pirate ever to sail, has come to visit and even though the bounty on his head has climbed 'ten thousand, thirty, fifty thousand doubloons?!' still nobody would take them, for none cross....you!

I've been playing this game for years now, it's my every now and then game where I'll play one or two careers. Even though it's old, I still get a great kick. It's terribly easy until you're at least a Rougue Captain, but as your character ages, you become slower and all skill fade with age. It's a good, quickish game which will instantly make you happy.
If you're not into older games, then this one isn't for you. It is limited in areas, but it's the perfect game for people who enjoy funny, non taxing games that don't require considerable time or background attention or anyone who enjoys Sid Meier as a rule.

reviewText:
Best couple of quid I ever spent, getting this on the Steam Summer Sale.

================
Pros:
+ Despite being utterly dated, the art style of this game is compelling
+ There's no shortage of variety, with half a dozen minigames to flesh out the moving around doing stuff" experience
+ Really sells the Caribbean with a lovingly crafted map full of hidden objects and items
+ Rewards proactive adventure-buccaneering
date:
while not forcing it down your throat
+ The Governors' Daughters ('nuff said)
+ PIRATES

- Some of the minigames (looking at you land battles) are a wee bit unpolished and somewhat overstay their welcome
- The art style of this game is compelling
recommended: but it *is* utterly dated\n- That painful crawl East across the open sea
hoursPlayed:
especially on lower difficulties when the wind never changes direction
- A few (infrequent) game breaking bugs - one of which could be a major epilepsy trigger

If you're willing to brave the storms that inherently come with a period-piece of a game
voteText:
then there's a lot to love about Sid Meier's Pirates.

reviewText: After putting in my 40+ hours at the desk job, it's nice to come home to a rewarding game that doesn't require too much brain power.  At around ten dollars, this kept me entertained, relaxed, and engaged for most of a weekend.  It is well worth the cost.  Many developers now are pushing for a more real-life experience with darker visuals and more deeply challenging  game play, but I don't want to play those types of games all the time.  There's still plenty of room left on the SSD for brighter, happier visuals and simpler, joyful games.  I did run into a bug once where my ship got stuck, but the fix is to reload the last autosave battle, and you're unstuck... no big deal.
